Title: Mark Carney set to become Canada's new Prime Minister after Liberal party victory
Description: Carney, 59, will succeed Justin Trudeau, who announced in January that he would step down amid low approval ratings following a decade in office. (Image credit: Jason Franson)

Title: More than 1,300 Syrians killed in 72 hours amid clashes and acts of revenge
Description: A human rights group characterized the killings as executions and massacres, carried out in revenge against the Alawite community, which made up Assad's longtime base of support. (Image credit: Moawia Atras)

Title: Thousands of online scam workers are stuck in limbo in Myanmar
Description: NPR's Scott Detrow speaks with journalist Jan Camenzind Broomby about the thousands of people who are stuck in limbo after being caught in online scam centers in Myanmar but who can't return home.

Title: Trump rebuffed by Iran's leader after sending letter calling for nuclear negotiation
Description: Iran's UN mission says its open to limited talks over 'militarization' of its nuclear program (Image credit: AP)

Title: Pope Francis pens prayer thanking hospital staff, as he shows 'mild improvement'
Description: The Holy See Press Office said the pontiff has shown 'a good response to the therapies.' He was hospitalized on Feb. 14 for a case of bronchitis. (Image credit: Christopher Furlong)

Title: NPR investigation finds a widespread culture of abuse in federal court system
Description: An NPR investigation finds problems with the federal court system and a deep culture of fear about reporting judges for abusive behavior and sexual harassment.

Title: U.S. Secret Service says it shot a man near the White House after a confrontation
Description: A man who was brandishing a firearm in Washington, D.C., was shot by Secret Service officers near the White House on Sunday morning, the Secret Service said. (Image credit: Ron Edmonds)

Title: The Trump administration claims credit for a quiet border. The data shows otherwise
Description: The U.S.-Mexico border is quieter than it's been in years. Vice President Vance says the Trump administration deserves the credit, but migrant apprehensions have been falling for months.

Title: Cleveland Mayor Justin Bibb says Trump's 'America First' agenda is hurting the city
Description: NPR's Ayesha Rascoe speaks with Cleveland mayor Justin Bibb who argues that President Trump's budget cuts and funding freezes will hurt cities like his.

Title: This synagogue calls itself 'anti-Zionist.' Here's what that means in practice
Description: Tzedek Chicago calls itself anti-Zionist congregation, meaning it does not support a Jewish nation-state. (Image credit: Yonat Shimron)

Title: 60 years after Bloody Sunday in Alabama, elusive racial progress in Selma
Description: Events in Selma, Ala. six decades ago helped win support for the 1965 Voting Rights Act. Today local activists say they're still fighting stubborn segregation, poverty and gun violence. (Image credit: AFP)

Title: Trump DOJ's limits on FACE Act enforcement fuel concern from abortion providers
Description: New Justice Department leaders say past enforcement of the Freedom of Access to Clinic Entrances Act is 'the prototypical example' of what they call 'the weaponization of law enforcement.' (Image credit: Jon Cherry)

Title: New York governor declares state of emergency for brush fires on Long Island
Description: Fast-moving brush fires fanned by high winds burned through a large swath of land on New York's Long Island on Saturday, prompting the evacuation of a military base and the closure of a major highway. (Image credit: Steve Pfost)

Title: Experts warn that recent school shootings show growth in new radicalization pattern
Description: Some researchers say these recent attacks are examples of 'nonideological' terrorism — the result of several antisocial, decentralized, online networks coming together. (Image credit: Morry Gash)

Title: Intensifying violence tests new Syrian government
Description: In Syria, fighting is intensifying as clashes between Syrian security forces and gunmen loyal to former President Bashar Assad have left hundreds of people dead.

Title: One Texan's quest to create a state-wide hiking trail
Description: Texas isn't best seen from behind the steering wheel, but through shades, wearing hiking shoes on a walking trail. Now a Texan is making big strides on creating a walking trail called the X-Tx, stretching from the Louisiana border all the way to New Mexico, a 1,550-mile stroll that will be among the longest trails in the country. The trail will go through natural beauties from the Hill country/central Texas, Big Bend National Park and the Guadalupe mountains –highest point in the state-- surrounded by the Chihuahuan desert from west Texas. Texas Public Radio's Jack Morgan finds out how they plan to build the X-Tx. 4m piece + digital. Texas Public Radio's Jack Morgan. Target: week of 2/24. Alfredo edit.

Title: Vatican says hospitalized Pope Francis is showing 'gradual, slight improvement'
Description: The 88-year-old pontiff is responding well to the treatment for double pneumonia and has shown a 'gradual, slight improvement' in recent days, the Vatican said Saturday. (Image credit: Andrew Medichini)

Title: D.C.'s Black Lives Matter mural will be erased. Look back at the iconic street painting
Description: Over the past five years, Washington, D.C.'s iconic Black Lives Matter street painting has served as a powerful symbol of activism and a gathering place for joy and resistance. (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: GOP unveils stopgap bill to avert a government shutdown. They may not have the votes.
Description: House Republicans released the text of a continuing resolution that would fund the government through Sept. 30. Now, passing it in a narrowly divided chamber is the next hurdle. (Image credit: Zayrha Rodriguez)

Title: Opinion: Thailand's deportation of Uyghurs to China has echoes of 10 years ago
Description: Thailand's recent deportations of Uyghurs to China have eerie parallels with a large deportation in 2015, in which the country bowed to Beijing, writes historian Jeffrey Wasserstrom. (Image credit: Chanakarn Laosarakham)

Title: States sue Trump administration over mass firings of federal employees
Description: The District of Columbia, Maryland and 18 other states have filed a lawsuit in federal court seeking the reinstatement of tens of thousands of federal employees fired since mid-February. (Image credit: Jim Watson)

Title: Montana's solution to rising property values: taxing wealthy, out-of-state homeowners
Description: As property values rise, Montana is seeking to cut taxes for most properties but raise them for out-of-state homeowners.

Title: Newly restored photos show the ruin of 'Bloody Sunday' in Selma on its 60th anniversary
Description: James 'Spider' Martin was assigned to photograph the protests in Alabama after civil rights activist Jimmie Lee Jackson was killed by state troopers. (Image credit: Spider Martin)

Title: Dairy farmers in Wisconsin see federal funding unfrozen as others are left waiting
Description: Dozens of Wisconsin dairy farmers are breathing a sigh of relief after federal funds they had been awarded were released and payments are now being promised. But anxiety persists for some. (Image credit: Chuck Quirmbach)

Title: A South Carolina prisoner is the first executed by a firing squad in 15 years
Description: A South Carolina man who killed his ex-girlfriend's parents with a baseball bat was executed by firing squad Friday, the first U.S. prisoner in 15 years to die by that method. (Image credit: Chris Carlson)

Title: Trump signs executive action targeting public service loan program
Description: The program forgives the loans of borrowers who work in public service. The executive action would exclude those who work for certain organizations. (Image credit: Brynn Anderson)

Title: Marco Rubio pivots to America First diplomacy
Description: It's been a little more than a week since Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy met with President Donald Trump in the Oval Office. Vice President JD Vance was in the meeting too. And Secretary of State Marco Rubio, the nation's top diplomat, sat on an Oval Office couch, mostly silent, as Trump and Vance berated the Ukrainian leader. Along the way, the president and vice president made it clear just how much of the established global order they are ready to upend. An order that for most of his career, Rubio has defended, and worked to help hold up. So what changed ...and what do those changes mean? For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org</a...

Title: Hong Kong company sells its ports in Panama, says it's business, not politics
Description: Hong Kong tycoon Li Ka-shing's CK Hutchison Holdings sold its Panama ports business to a group of investors led by BlackRock. What does this episode tell us about Hong Kong today?

Title: The soundtrack to King Charles' life features music from Kylie Minogue
Description: King Charles III has admitted he is not impervious to a generational earworm like Kylie Minogue's 'Can't Get You Out of My Head,' after sharing a playlist that represents the soundtrack of his life. (Image credit: Central Press/Getty Images)

Title: Nablus soap gets UNESCO recognition in Israeli-occupied West Bank
Description: An ancient soap-making tradition in the Israeli-occupied West Bank has been added to the UNESCO list of Intangible Cultural Heritage. NPR visits one of the oldest soap factories in the city of Nablus.

Title: Trump administration cancels $400 million in federal dollars for Columbia University
Description: The administration said it was cancelling grants and other federal awards for Columbia for an alleged failure to protect Jewish students from antisemitism. (Image credit: Alex Kent)

Title: Gene Hackman died of heart disease, his wife died of hantavirus, authorities say
Description: Actor Gene Hackman died of heart disease a full week after his wife died from hantavirus in their New Mexico hillside home, authorities revealed Friday. (Image credit: Chris Pizzello)

Title: A Lagos community, destroyed in one day
Description: At least 9,000 people have been forcefully evicted from a riverside community in Nigeria's most populous city, Lagos. Like many waterfront communities across the city, it has faced multiple threats and been targeted by luxury real estate developers. (Image credit: Sunday Alamba/AP)

Title: President Trump brings back practice of detaining families together
Description: President Trump — and several other former presidents — also detained families during his first term in an effort to deter migration through the southern border. (Image credit: Veronica G. Cardenas/POOL)

Title: New research reveals ancient humans used animal bone tools much earlier than thought
Description: The handcrafted tools found in Tanzania were made 1.5 million years ago and were fashioned primarily from the bones of elephants and hippopotamuses. (Image credit: CSIC)

Title: The Dangerous Popularity of Skin Whitening Products in Nigeria
Description: In many parts of the world skin whitening is a major industry, but women in Nigeria have a particular fondness for creams and lotions that promise to lighten their skin. By one estimate, over 77% of women in the country have used such products. We go to Nigeria and learn that the effects of skin whiteners can be severe and many people who use them are unable to stop.

Title: A former Olympic snowboarder makes the FBI's Most Wanted list
Description: Ryan Wedding, a former Canadian Olympic snowboarder-turned-alleged-drug trafficker, 'went from shredding powder on the slopes at the Olympics to distributing powder cocaine,' the FBI says. (Image credit: Damian Dovarganes)

Title: Syria imposes curfew after its worst clashes since the Assad regime ouster
Description: Syria's new government sent in security reinforcements and imposed curfews on a coastal area after major clashes with fighters loyal to the deposed Syrian President Bashar al-Assad. (Image credit: Omar Albam)

Title: War heroes are among 26,000 images flagged for removal in Pentagon's DEI purge
Description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth had given the military until Wednesday to remove content highlighting diversity efforts following an executive order ending those programs across the government. (Image credit: Sgt. Tyler Main)

Title: A look at some of the creative ways companies try to dodge high tariffs
Description: Companies can try to avoid or minimize tariffs by requesting exemptions or legally reclassifying their products. Here's a look at some of the strategies that have worked in the past. (Image credit: Brandon Bell)

Title: Monthly jobs report to be released. And, the White House to host a crypto event
Description: The Labor Department will release the monthly jobs report card today, which is expected to show solid growth. But that's not the whole picture. And, the White House will host a cryptocurrency summit.

Title: Farmers strongly back Trump. A new trade war could test their loyalty
Description: American farmers have stood firmly behind President Trump even when his trade policies hurt them. The latest trade war, which could be even worse for their sector, promises to test those ties again. (Image credit: Joshua A. Bickel)

Title: Afghans in Pakistan awaiting U.S. resettlement are stuck in a treacherous limbo
Description: The Trump administration has halted the U.S. refugee program, Pakistan is taking steps to force Afghans out — and their lives may be at risk if they return to their own country. (Image credit: Betsy Joles for NPR)

Title: Trump says nobody has heard of Lesotho. Can you answer our quiz question about it?
Description: It was another action-packed week, with the Academy Awards, Mardi Gras and the president's address to Congress. Did you pay attention?

Title: Why VA mental health workers feel Elon Musk's emails are psychological warfare
Description: Mental health professionals with the Veterans Health Administration say the stress caused by Elon Musk's 'What did you do last week?' emails is hurting veterans' care. (Image credit: Deagreez/iStockphoto/Getty Images)

Title: Why the Trump administration is negotiating directly with Hamas
Description: Why is the U.S. negotiating with Hamas, in conflict with policy to not negotiate with U.S.-designated terrorist groups? NPR speaks with Brian Katulis, senior fellow at the Middle East Institute.

Title: Uncertainty grows surrounding the ceasefire in Gaza between Israel and Hamas
Description: The first phase of the ceasefire deal between Israel and Hamas ended with no agreement on what comes next. President Trump is demanding that Hamas immediately free all of its remaining hostages.

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Labor Department to release monthly jobs report card, President Trump to speak to cryptocurrency founders and investors at the White House, uncertainty grows over ceasefire between Israel and Hamas.

Title: Georgia factory resumes peanut paste production for starving children overseas
Description: Lifesaving peanut paste for malnourished children is being produced again at a Georgia factory after the Trump administration reversed course on a canceled USAID contract.

Title: How a measles outbreak overwhelmed a small west Texas town
Description: There's an unusual health scare in far west Texas right now. The disease that's spreading, the measles, was thought to have been a thing of the past. The CDC declared it eliminated from the United States in 2000. But health officials have now confirmed some 80 cases in Gaines County and they expect the number to rise. This part of Texas is home to a large Mennonite population. And a lot of those folks shun vaccinations, making them vulnerable to the disease, which is highly contagious. Gaines County had the highest unvaccinated rate in Texas this school year at 18 percent, according to state health data. Some health officials worry that the politicization of vaccines has led even more parents to forgo vaccinating their young children, leading to outbreaks like this one. And this community ...

Title: Nearly 5 years after George Floyd murder, Minneapolis PD turns to LAPD for lessons
Description: Nearly five years after George Floyd's murder by a Minneapolis police officer, the force is taking lessons from Los Angeles police who worked through the aftermath of the 1992 beating of Rodney King.

Title: If you see something (woke), say something
Description: Code Switch's Gene Demby looks into the Department of Education's new end-DEI portal that asks Americans to narc on their local public schools.

Title: Unexploded WWII bomb in Paris halts Eurostar travel to London
Description: The French transport minister said traffic would be ''strongly disrupted'' throughout the day with only limited service resuming in the afternoon, and urged travelers to postpone their trips. (Image credit: Christophe Ena)

Title: Five takeaways: China's foreign minister slams Trump's 'two-faced' policies
Description: China's top foreign policy official addressed the escalating trade war with the U.S. and promoted China as an 'anchor' on the global stage as America retreats from international involvement. (Image credit: Ng Han Guan)

Title: Walgreens agrees to be acquired by private equity firm for almost $10 billion
Description: A buyout to take the drugstore chain private would give it more flexibility to make changes to improve its business without worrying about Wall Street's reaction. (Image credit: Gene J. Puskar)

Title: Court orders South Korean President Yoon released from jail
Description: The decision would allow Yoon to stand his criminal trial while not being physically detained. The court is expected to rule soon on whether to uphold his impeachment or remove him from office. (Image credit: Ahn Young-joon)

Title: SpaceX loses contact with spacecraft during Starship mega rocket test flight
Description: Nearly two months after an explosion sent flaming debris raining down on the Turks and Caicos, SpaceX launched another mammoth Starship rocket but lost contact minutes into the test flight. (Image credit: Eric Gay)

Title: The European Union Decides to Rearm
Description: Leaders of the European Union have voted to approve a plan to dramatically increase defense spending. The move is a reaction to the U.S. reducing its support for Ukraine in the war against Russia's invasion. We go to Brussels to understand the ramifications. And we hear what the series of recent developments in the relationship between the U.S. and Ukraine could mean for peace talks with Russia. (Image credit: HATIM KAGHAT)

Title: When it comes to the economy, it's all about uncertainty
Description: Like a lot of economists, Mark Zandi, with Moody's Analytics, thinks President Trump's across-the-board tariffs are a bad idea. Saying, 'Tariffs, broad-based tariffs, are a real problem for the economy.'But Zandi says – it's not just the tariffs themselves that are the problem, it's the uncertainty created by Trump's rollout. Trump threatened 25% Tariffs on Canada and Mexico would start in February. They were paused at the 11th hour, only to eventually go into effect this week.On Thursday Trump announced the new tariffs would be paused for most products, but potentially only until April 2.Meanwhile tariffs on China snapped into place in February, and then doubled, to 20%.What happens next is anyone's guess. Businesses have been optimistic about the e...

Title: California man charged after Lego larceny worth $25,000
Description: The heists occurred in several California counties, where the alleged thief would load his shopping cart with the expensive building toys and disappear into the parking lot in a matter of minutes. (Image credit: Dan Kitwood)

Title: Democracy-promoting organization sues the Trump administration over withheld funds
Description: President Ronald Reagan laid the rhetorical foundations for the National Endowment for Democracy in a 1982 speech to the British Parliament. Support for its creation in Congress was bipartisan. (Image credit: Fox Photos/Hulton Archive)

Title: At a housewares expo in Chicago, talk keeps turning to price hikes from tariffs
Description: The Inspired Home Show in Chicago draws housewares industry insiders from all over the country to network and show off their latest gadgets. This year, they're making plans to cope with tariffs.

Title: South Korean fighter jets drop bombs in the wrong place, injuring 8 people
Description: The air force said the jets were taking part in a drill with the U.S. military in Pocheon, a city close to the border with North Korea, when they dropped bombs just outside a firing range. (Image credit: Yonhap)

Title: Fighter jets accidentally drop bombs during exercises, injuring 8 South Koreans
Description: The air force said the jets were taking part in a drill with the U.S. military in Pocheon, a city close to the border with North Korea, when they dropped bombs just outside a firing range. (Image credit: /)

Title: Palestinians freed in the ceasefire say Israeli forces harass them and their families
Description: Several Palestinian prisoners and detainees freed during this ceasefire deal have been harassed by Israeli forces after their release, their homes raided or their family members arrested. (Image credit: Afif H. Amireh for NPR)

Title: Steve Carell announces that a charity will fund proms for students affected by LA fires
Description: The children's organization, Alice's Kids, will cover the costs for approximately 800 students to enjoy prom night. (Image credit: Dia Dipasupil)

Title: Layoffs and potential closures of key facilities raise worries about NOAA's future
Description: The Trump administration may end leases for some of NOAA's offices while the agency terminates several advisory committees at the important weather and climate agency. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: Automakers granted relief from tariffs. And, fired USDA workers return to work
Description: President Trump announced a one-month reprieve from import tariffs for automakers after he imposed them on Canada and Mexico. And, thousands of fired USDA workers return to work today.

Title: As Canadians cancel trips due to Trump, the U.S. tourism industry could lose billions
Description: The Trump administration's attacks on its northern neighbor have been met with confusion and anger by some Canadians who are now cancelling their trips to the U.S. in protest. (Image credit: Patrick T. Fallon)

Title: How does the U.S. federal workforce compare with those in other countries?
Description: President Trump's administration has fired more than 20,000 federal workers. How does the federal workforce compare with those of other countries? (Image credit: Kevin Dietsch)

Title: State Supreme Court races can be costly, competitive and combative. Why?
Description: Wisconsin is on track to break spending records once again in a high court contest that's at times turned heated. But these races weren't always like this. (Image credit: Angela Major)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: EU leaders to hold emergency meeting on Ukraine support and Russian threats, Trump grants automakers one-month reprieve from tariffs, nearly 6,000 USDA workers fired by Trump ordered back to work.

Title: European Union leaders hold emergency summit on Ukraine support
Description: European Union leaders are expected to discuss rapidly increasing defense budgets. There's new urgency after President Trump paused military supplies and intelligence sharing with Ukraine. (Image credit: Geert Vanden Wijngaert)

Title: EU leaders to hold emergency summit on Ukraine support, Russian threats to continent
Description: EU leaders are gathering for an emergency summit to coordinate support for Ukraine and to protect the continent from Russian threats. They are expected to discuss rapidly increasing defense budgets.

Title: What peace talks between Russia, Ukraine and the U.S. might look like
Description: What could peace talks between Russia, Ukraine and the U.S. look like? NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Bob Hamilton, head of Eurasia research at the Foreign Policy Research Institute.

Title: North Carolina nonprofit helping dispel panic and rumors amid immigration crackdown
Description: President Trump demands cities and states cooperate with immigration enforcement. In immigrant communities, that's led to panic and many rumors. A North Carolina nonprofit is helping dispel them.

Title: Israel threatens intervention in Syrian capital Damascus due to unrest there
Description: A suburb of Damascus is at the center of the new Syrian government's struggle for control. Now, Israel is threatening to intervene due to unrest there, turning this into an international incident.

Title: Rural Alaskan schools are crumbling as the state fails to provide funding to fix them
Description: Rural schools in Alaska are plagued with health and safety issues. The state has failed for nearly two decades to provide the funding needed to fix them, despite repeated requests.

Title: How tax cuts on Social Security benefits would impact the program's longevity
Description: President Trump has promised again to cut taxes on Social Security benefits. NPR asks the Committee for a Responsible Budget's Marc Goldwein about the potential impact on the program's longevity.

Title: Lesotho officials shocked by Trump's remarks that 'nobody' has heard of their country
Description: Government officials in the small African country of Lesotho were shocked by President Trump's dismissive remarks that 'nobody has ever heard' of their country.

Title: Iowan with a transgender child reacts to state's elimination of protections
Description: Iowa eliminated anti-discrimination protections for transgender people from its civil rights law. NPR's Leila Fadel talks to Matt McIver, an Iowan with a transgender child.

Title: Ukrainian Americans deeply concerned about the U-turn in U.S.-Ukraine relations
Description: Philadelphia and parts of New Jersey have some of the country's largest populations of Ukrainian Americans. Many are deeply concerned about the turn in U.S.-Ukraine relations.

Title: Trump prepares order dismantling the Education Department
Description: The draft executive action, obtained by NPR, acknowledges the department and its signature responsibilities were created by Congress, and cannot legally be altered without congressional approval. (Image credit: Jose Luis Magana/AP)

Title: Trump administration can remove head of federal watchdog agency, appeals court rules
Description: A U.S. appeals court has sided with the administration in allowing the removal of Hampton Dellinger from the Office of Special Counsel. The office investigates actions like whistleblower retaliation. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: Trump says tariffs will help stop fentanyl. Many of his claims on the crisis are untrue
Description: Trump continues to link his tariffs to fentanyl and overdose deaths — in his speech to Congress and on social media. But many of his statements about the fentanyl crisis aren't factual.

Title: A CDC worker was fired. Then unexpectedly got her job back. She's not sure what to do
Description: CDC Public Health Associate Bri McNulty, who talked to NPR about being summarily fired last week, got an email that she had her job back. In the meantime, McNulty got a job offer at Penn State.

Title: Nobel Peace Prize winner Lech Walesa condemns President Trump's treatment of Zelenskyy
Description: Nobel Peace Prize winner Lech Walesa expresses fear and distaste at how Trump treats Ukrainian president Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

Title: A look into Iran's economic woes
Description: President Trump wants to squeeze Iran's economy by reducing its crude oil exports to zero. But Iran's economy has already been in freefall for months.

Title: What to know about Lesotho, the country Trump said 'nobody has ever heard of'
Description: President Trump defended his humanitarian aid cuts to countries around the globe, including one nation he joked 'nobody has ever heard of.' Here are some facts about the African nation of Lesotho. (Image credit: Themba Hadebe)

Title: By the numbers: Does LeBron James' new points record shake up the GOAT debate?
Description: LeBron James has been so good for so long, there's a famous running joke about when he might slow down. At age 40, where does his 50,000 career points record put him in the GOAT debate? (Image credit: Sean M. Haffey)

Title: In a first, the 2026 World Cup final will include a halftime show
Description: Like the Super Bowl mid-game spectaculars, the 2026 final game slated to take place at MetLife Stadium in New Jersey will include the World Cup's very first halftime show. (Image credit: Richard Heathcote)

Title: Going Back in Time to Soviet Central Asia's Boogie Nights
Description: Today we take a break from the serious and often depressing international news beat to bring you the sound's of Soviet Central Asia in the 1970's and 80's. Our Moscow correspondent introduces us to an anthology of songs that came out of a record factory in Tashkent documenting a wide variety of music from the silk road in that time period.

Title: In a policy shift, U.S. and Hamas say they're in direct talks on hostages
Description: A Hamas official tells NPR that the United States has held direct talks with the Palestinian militant group over the release of several American-Israeli dual citizens taken hostage during the Oct. 7, 2023, attacks in Israel. (Image credit: Eyad Baba)

Title: Dozens of Canadians are charged for scamming American grandparents out of $21 million
Description: The 25 Canadians are accused of calling seniors in over 40 states, pretending to be their grandchildren and asking for bail money. Authorities warn such scams are getting increasingly sophisticated. (Image credit: Bernd Weißbrod)

Title: More than 5,000 USDA workers fired by Trump ordered back to work for now
Description: The U.S. Department of Agriculture must temporarily reinstate more than 5,000 probationary employees fired since Feb. 13, according to a ruling by the Merit Systems Protection Board. (Image credit: Saul Loeb)

Title: Meet the Syrians behind the music that inspired a revolution
Description: Syrian soccer player Abdel Basset al-Sarout became the poster child for the Syrian revolution with his iconic protest anthems. In death, he has become its saint. But he didn't do it alone. (Image credit: Yahya Nemah for NPR)

Title: Supreme Court upholds lower court order to force USAID to pay contractors
Description: In an order, the justices left in place a lower court order that so far has only required the Trump administration to pay contractors for foreign aid work that has already been completed — roughly $2 billion. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Takeaways from Trump's address to Congress. And, China projects confidence in economy
Description: President Trump delivered a partisan address to a joint session of Congress last night, boasting about his accomplishments from the first six weeks. And, China projects confidence in its economy. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: What went wrong? Israel's spy agency lists failures in preventing Oct. 7 attack
Description: Israel's domestic security agency had Hamas' battle plans for the Oct. 7, 2023 attacks but didn't take them seriously. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu deflected responsibility for the failure. (Image credit: Amir Levy)

Title: God walks with us through the ashes.' A poignant Ash Wednesday after LA wildfires
Description: On Ash Wednesday, Christians hear the words 'Remember that you are dust and to dust you shall return.' Those words ring differently for many whose churches and homes burned in the Los Angeles fires. (Image credit: Jason DeRose)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: A recap of President Trump's address to a joint session of Congress, Trump touts success of some of his immigration policies during address, and China opens its annual session of parliament.

Title: Virginia Sen. Tim Kaine plans to force Republicans to vote on Trump's Canada tariffs
Description: Republicans are 'nervous' about President Trump's tariffs raising prices, says Democratic Sen. Tim Kaine of Virginia. He plans to force a vote in the Senate on them soon. (Image credit: Nathan Posner)

Title: Central Asian Soviet-era pop music anthology dislays the region's vast diversity
Description: A Central Asian Soviet-era pop music anthology shines a light on the region's ethnic diversity and music that transcends genres from Korean Brass Bands to Uyghur garage rock to Crimean jazz.

Title: As Washington changes course on Ukraine, Taiwan wonders about its own fate
Description: Thousands of miles away from Ukraine, Taiwan is wondering whether it will be the next casualty of the changing moods in Washington, D.C. — and about what they can do to avoid a similar fate.

Title: In Key West, testing shows cruise ships stir up as much sediment as a hurricane
Description: Tests in Key West show sediment stirred up by cruise ships, which can harm marine life, routinely exceed federal standards. Key West has responded by suspending the tests. (Image credit: Handan Khanna)

Title: Federal hiring is nearly frozen. For those who can hire, a new roadblock has emerged
Description: Some federal agencies, like the Department of Veterans Affairs, are largely exempt from President Trump's hiring freeze. But they're hitting a new roadblock in bringing new staff on. (Image credit: Tierney L. Cross)

Title: Some VA hospitals hitting roadblocks in their hiring processes
Description: Some federal agencies, like the Department of Veterans Affairs, are largely exempt from President Trump's hiring freeze. But they're hitting a new roadblock in onboarding staff.

Title: Volunteers in Altadena race to save historic tiles after the LA wildfires
Description: Chimneys are all that are left of many homes that burned in Altadena. Some are adorned with historic tiles, and a group of volunteers are racing to save them before bulldozers come and clear debris.

Title: Trump touts success of some of his immigration policies in address to Congress
Description: President Trump campaigned on border security and strict immigration policy. In his address to a joint session of Congress Tuesday night, he argued he had succeeded in implementing some of his goals.

Title: Elon Musk to send another email to check for non-existent federal workers
Description: Elon Musk says he will send another email to more than 2 million federal workers to see whether they have a pulse. Why is the idea of non-existent employees an animating principle for Musk?

Title: Why a small Colorado town wants to buy its neighboring ski resort
Description: Big conglomerates dominate ownership of America's ski resorts. When a Colorado ski hill went up for sale, a neighboring town launched a bid to buy it to preserve its relaxed culture and affordability.

Title: A look at the human toll of the construction of the Panama Canal
Description: The Panama Canal's impact on the geopolitical stage far outreaches its roughly 51-mile stretch of land and water. This week, we're trying to understand the canal's murky future - from climate change to President Trump's threat to take it for the U.S. - by looking at its turbulent, cataclysmic birth.

Title: China's parliament opens with confidence about the economy despite tariffs, headwinds
Description: China will aim for economic growth of around 5% this year, the same as last year. This comes despite deep domestic challenges and fresh tariffs on Chinese imports to the U.S. (Image credit: Andy Wong)

Title: Cybercrime crew stole then resold hundreds of tickets to Swift shows, prosecutors say
Description: Prosecutors say the majority of the stolen tickets were for Swift's Eras Tour, but the thieves also boosted ones for Adele and Ed Sheeran concerts, NBA games and the U.S. Open Tennis Championships. (Image credit: Lindsey Wasson)

Title: From cheers to protests, here's a look inside the chamber during Trump's speech

Title: An abrupt departure as USAID workers return to clear their desks at DC headquarters.
Description: The Trump administration has been dismantling the US Agency for International Development, and the headquarters have been closed for weeks. But, on Thursday, workers got to go back to their desks - to clean them out and leave.

Title: USAID workers return to HQ to clear their desks, as Trump dismantles the agency
Description: Workers who served in the U.S. Agency for International Development were allowed a final and brief visit back to their offices to clear out their belongings on Thursday. (Image credit: Manuel Balce Ceneta)

Title: Court considers halting Trump's mass firings of federal employees
Description: A federal judge in San Francisco hears arguments in a case challenging the Trump administration's firings of thousands of probationary employees — those in their first year or so on the job. (Image credit: Jacquelyn Martin/AP)

Title: ICE will reopen a major detention center in New Jersey as it eyes a broader expansion
Description: The Trump administration is expanding its immigration detention capacity, reopening a 1,000-bed detention center in New Jersey and adding beds at other privately owned facilities around the country. (Image credit: ICE via)

Title: Martin Marty, leading scholar of American religion, dies at 97
Description: Martin Marty, one of the foremost interpreters of religion in American public life, died on Tuesday. He was 97 years old. (Image credit: Photo courtesy University of Chicago.)

Title: 2 years after Greece's deadliest train crash, victims and families await answers
Description: On Feb. 28, 2023, a passenger train and freight train collided, leaving 57 dead. New evidence suggests many may not have been killed by the crash itself, but by a fire that followed. (Image credit: SAKIS MITROLIDIS)

Title: Trump says he doesn't see need for U.S. security guarantees to end Ukraine-Russia war
Description: In a meeting with the British Prime Minister, Trump said reaching a peace deal would be the 'difficult part.' He said security would be made easier by a U.S. deal with Ukraine on critical minerals. (Image credit: Carl Court)

Title: Andrew Tate, facing rape and trafficking charges in Romania, is back in the U.S.
Description: The Tate brothers have been allowed to leave Romania, where they were charged with human trafficking, rape and forming a criminal group to sexually exploit women. They arrived in Florida on Thursday. (Image credit: Marta Lavandier)

Title: The U.S. resumes hundreds of millions in security aid to Taiwan, annoying China
Description: The U.S. has unfrozen millions in security assistance for Taiwan, with an eye toward China. (Image credit: I-Hwa Cheng)

Title: Pentagon directs removal of trans service members from military
Description: Service members and recruits who are diagnosed with or treated for gender dysphoria are to be separated from the U.S. military in accordance with an executive order issued a month ago by President Trump. (Image credit: Jim Watson)

Title: Syrian Jews return to Damascus for the first time in decades, hoping to build bridges
Description: Thousands of Jews left Syria in 1992, when they were allowed to emigrate. The visit by a small delegation of U.S.-based Syrian Jewish religious figures last week was their first time back since then. (Image credit: Ayman Oghanna for NPR)

Title: Republican Sen. Josh Hawley discusses his mission to hold big tech accountable
Description: Republican Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri talks about his mission to hold tech companies accountable even as they try to align themselves with President Donald Trump.

Title: Trump administration cuts most USAID programs. And, the ethics of leaving your job
Description: Nearly all USAID programs have been eliminated. One official says it's a 'global health massacre.' And, a federal judge will hear arguments over the decision to fire thousands of probationary workers. (Image credit: Jam Sta Rosa)

Title: Thailand deports dozens of Uyghurs to China, activists say
Description: The detainees were part of a group of some 300 Uyghurs who fled China and were arrested in Thailand in 2014. Thailand deported more than 100 of them to China in 2015, drawing condemnation. (Image credit: Haruka Nuga)

Title: Language as protagonist in Cristina Rivera Garza's newly translated novel
Description: Pulitzer winner Cristina Rivera Garza offers new perspective on gender violence through a murder mystery and poetry.

Title: A rare 'parade' of all 7 planets will move across the night sky this week
Description: This phenomenon known as a 'planet parade,' will feature Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, Saturn, Uranus and Neptune all present at the same time along a line in the night sky on Friday, NASA says. (Image credit: NASA/JPL-Caltech)

Title: How Trump's crackdown plays into misperceptions about immigrants and crime
Description: The White House portrays its immigration crackdown as a success. Critics say the administration is trying to look tough for the cameras, and worry about the 'tail wagging the dog.'

Title: Morning news brief
Description: Trump administration ending thousands of foreign assistance grants and awards, Venezuelan men allege mistreatment at Guantánamo, judge to hear arguments on dismissal of probationary federal employees.

Title: What Greenlanders say about Trump's plans for the territory
Description: President Trump says he wants to take over Greenland. Some of the Danish territory's roughly 57,000 residents share how they feel about the island's current ties with the U.S. and Denmark.

Title: Federal judge to hear arguments on dismissal on probationary federal employees
Description: The Trump administration is facing legal challenges as it moves to shrink the federal workforce. A judge will hear arguments Thursday on whether dismissal of probationary employees should be halted.

Title: 4 thoughts on Trump's aggression toward Europe from EU's foreign policy chief
Description: President Trump is threatening the European Union with steep tariffs. The EU's foreign policy chief said leaders there wonder what they've done to warrant such treatment. (Image credit: Virginia Mayo)

Title: European Union foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas discusses shifting U.S. alliances
Description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with European Union foreign policy chief Kaja Kallas {Ky-uh KAL-uss} about how the E.U. views shifting U.S. alliances.

Title: Republican Sen. Josh Hawley discusses his mission to hold big tech accountable
Description: Republican Senator Josh Hawley of Missouri talks about his mission to hold tech companies accountable even as they try to align themselves with President Donald Trump.

Title: Hamas returns bodies of four hostages and Israel releases hundreds of Palestinians
Description: Both sides agreed there would be no Hamas ceremonies for the hostage bodies and in exchange Israel would release the Palestinian detainees and prisoners whose freedom had been held up since Saturday. (Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)

Title: Taiwan condemns China for conducting shooting drills off its coast
Description: Taiwan said in a 24-hour period it detected 45 aircraft, 14 navy vessels and one ship from the Chinese military operating around Taiwan, of which 34 had crossed into its waters and airspace. (Image credit: AP)

Title: Trump cuts financial lifeline for Venezuela by ending permit to export oil to U.S.
Description: Trump's accused the government of Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro of not meeting democratic conditions for last year's July presidential election as well as of not moving fast enough to transport back immigrants set for deportation. (Image credit: Matias Delacroix)

Title: Over 7,000 from scam centers in Myanmar are awaiting repatriation after crackdown
Description: Trapped in virtual slavery, many are lured to work in scam centers where they exploit people around the world through false romances, bogus investment pitches and illegal gambling schemes. (Image credit: Thanaphon Wuttison)

Title: Oscar-nominated Brazilian film sparks debate about country's past
Description: Brazilians are flocking to the theaters to see its Oscar-nominated film I Am Still Here. It tells the story of a family devastated by the military dictatorship that ruled from 1964. There has never been a truth commission to investigate abuses or prosecutions of those accused of wrongdoing during a two-decade-long rule. Advocates hope the film might lead to a better understanding of that dark past. (Image credit: Amanda Edwards)

Title: Is there a deal to end Russia's war with Ukraine?
Description: On Friday, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy is scheduled to meet President Donald Trump at the White House.On the agenda — a deal for Ukraine to share its rich natural resources. The Trump administration wants hundreds of billions of dollars of rare earth metals and other critical minerals. Details are thin on what exactly Ukraine would get in exchange. The meeting comes as the world marks three years since Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and as Trump promises to bring an end to the war.But bringing an end to the war may not be so simple argues Alexander Vindman.The Uk...

Title: 14-year-old 'Human Calculator' sets mental math record
Description: There's a new Guinness World Record holder for how fast someone can do math. Aaryan Shukla -- who has been dubbed 'the human calculator' can solve complex problems in his head in seconds.

Title: Critics fear that President Trump's immigration crackdown plays into misperceptions
Description: The White House is touting its crackdown on illegal immigration. But critics worry it's putting optics ahead of substance, and reinforcing widely held misperceptions about immigrants and crime.

Title: 5 minerals in Ukraine that may be part of a deal with the U.S.
Description: President Trump says Ukraine is ready to sign a deal with the U.S. to share its mineral wealth. We look at five minerals and metals that could be covered by the deal. (Image credit: Sunday Alamba/AP)

Title: The search for the missing Malaysian Airlines Flight MH370 has resumed once again
Description: After 11 years of the plane's untraceable disappearance, authorities have announced that the search is back on. (Image credit: Rahman Roslan/Getty Images)

Title: A blackout left most of Chile in darkness for 7 hours
Description: For over seven straight hours in Chile, the electricity went out and plunged the country into chaos.

Title: How federal job cuts are playing out in Western states
Description: Red states with lots of federally owned land have long called agencies managing them 'bloated.' Now, agency job cuts are affecting local economies.

Title: As Elon Musk continues sweeping cuts to the US government: 'People are really scared'
Description: DOGE has eliminated thousands of federal jobs and canceled more than 1,000 contracts. Harvard professor Elizabeth Linos warns, 'We're seeing harms that are not going to be easily undone.'

Title: Trump suspends the head of 'The Nation's Report Card'
Description: Peggy Carr, a federal official who leads one of the country's most extensive student testing programs, known as The Nation's Report Card, was placed on administrative leave. (Image credit: Alex Brandon)

Title: U.K. Prime Minister Keir Starmer is set to visit the White House. Here's what to know
Description: In his visit on Thursday, the prime minister will try to leverage the U.K.'s so-called 'special relationship' with U.S. and act as a bridge between the Trump administration and U.S. allies in Europe. (Image credit: Leon Neal)

Title: The U.S. and Ukraine are close to agreeing on a framework deal for critical minerals
Description: President Trump says Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy will come to the U.S. Friday to sign a deal. (Image credit: Evgeniy Maloletka)

Title: How federal layoffs are impacting national parks, from reduced hours to safety fears
Description: Some 1,000 NPS employees were fired, and hiring for seasonal positions was delayed. Here's what to know about the impacts already being felt at parks, and what it could mean for the busy season. (Image credit: Brandon Bell)

Title: Trump's social media video garners pushback from Arabs and Muslims in U.S. and Gaza
Description: In a seemingly AI-generated video that the president posted on social media, images of destruction due to the war in Gaza are transformed into a glitzy resort called 'TRUMP GAZA.' (Image credit: Screenshots via Instagram. Annotation by NPR)

Title: The House passed a budget resolution. What's next? And, a tactic to decrease bird flu
Description: House Republicans rallied together yesterday to pass multitrillion-dollar plan to address defense, immigration and more. And, why farmers don't like the idea of vaccinating poultry for bird flu. (Image credit: Andrew Harnik)

Title: Israelis hold a mass funeral for Shiri Bibas and her two sons killed in Gaza
Description: Crowds gathered in Israel for the funeral procession of the Bibas family, a mother and two young sons killed while being held hostage in Gaza. The story of their killing has enraged Israelis, and Israeli government representatives were not invited to the funeral. (Image credit: Ariel Schalit)

Title: For Women's History Month, NPR wants to know who has made an impact in your life
Description: Is there a woman who has impacted your life in a profound way? NPR wants to hear your story. (Image credit: Kevin Winter)

Title: Tablets for tots? Survey says kids watch videos on their own devices by age 2
Description: A.I. is the other big change in the media landscape for kids and parents, the report from Common Sense Media finds. (Image credit: Riccardo Milani)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: House Republicans pass budget framework advancing Trump agenda, the conflicting messaging over who's in charge of some government decision-making, egg farmers say they're losing the bird flu battle.

Title: How Musk's efforts to reduce the federal workforce compare to efforts in the 1990s
Description: NPR speaks with Brookings' Elaine Kamarck about her 1990s effort to shrink the federal workforce and how it compares to Elon Musk's approach today. (Image credit: AP)

Title: How Musk's efforts to reduce the federal workforce compare to efforts in the 1990s
Description: NPR speaks with the Brookings Institution's Elaine Kamarck about her effort to reduce the size of the federal workforce during the 1990s and how it contrasts to Elon Musk's efforts today.

Title: Pope Francis is still in critical condition, but he had another 'restful night'
Description: Francis, 88, has been in critical condition for several days and he has remained absent from several regular appearances. The church has encouraged worshippers around the world to pray for his health. (Image credit: Andrew Medichini)

Title: Former deputy national security adviser in first Trump term defends shift on Europe
Description: Steve Inskeep speaks with Victoria Coates, former deputy national security adviser during the first Trump administration, about America's shifting international alliances.

Title: Israel and Hamas agree on a new exchange, leaving a fragile ceasefire intact
Description: The bodies of four Israeli hostages are to be returned late Wednesday and more than 600 Palestinian prisoners and detainees freed during the last week of the current Gaza ceasefire deal. (Image credit: Alexi J. Rosenfeld)

Title: A sweeping power blackout leaves most of Chile in darkness
Description: Internet and mobile phone services blinkered offline. People complained of water shortages as pumps stopped working. Emergency generators helped hospitals and government offices continue operating. (Image credit: Matias Basualdo)

Title: Federal board orders government to reinstate six workers fired by Trump
Description: The Merit Systems Protection Board, the quasi-judicial agency that hears appeals in federal employee labor disputes, has ordered a stay in the firing of six probationary employees. (Image credit: Krisanapong Detraphiphat)

Title: Southwest 737 and small business jet have 'near collision' at Chicago Midway Airport
Description: Federal authorities are investigating a near-collision at Chicago's Midway airport between a Southwest 737 and a small business jet. The 737 was landing when the business jet entered the runway. (Image credit: StreamTime Live)

Title: Judge tells Trump administration it has less than 2 days to resume USAID funding
Description: U.S. District Judge Amir H. Ali said officials have provided no evidence of compliance with repeated orders to unfreeze the money. (Image credit: Jam Sta Rosa/AFP via Getty Images)

Title: Diana Taurasi, 6-time Olympic gold medalist and the WNBA's top scorer, will retire
Description: Taurasi leaves her basketball career as the most decorated woman to ever play, with three WNBA titles, three NCAA titles and six Olympic gold medals to her name. (Image credit: Christian Petersen)

Title: Clearing Syria of unexploded munitions from the civil war
Description: During a brutal 14-year civil war, Syria's ousted regime dropped hundreds of thousands of bombs and munitions on its own civilians. Now Syria faces the challenge of clearing the unexploded munitions.

Title: Huntsville, Ala., hopes President Trump delivers on Space Command
Description: The city of Huntsville, Alabama has a lot to gain and possibly lose under the Trump administration. Known as the Rocket City, half of its GDP comes from the federal government.

Title: More than 40,000 Palestinians have been displaced in the West Bank in the last month
Description: More than 40,000 Palestinians have been displaced in the past month in the West Bank due to the Israel's prolonged military operation there. It's the largest displacement in the West Bank in decades.

Title: As Greenland prepares for tourism increase, a moment of stillness among the icebergs
Description: As Greenland resists U.S. acquisition threats, it's also welcoming an increase in tourism. Industry leaders and residents are preparing to make the island more accessible to visitors.

Title: Venezuelan men allege mistreatment while in detention in Guantánamo Bay
Description: The men told NPR they were kept in the dark about why they were in Guantánamo Bay, and were denied access to an attorney or a phone call with loved ones. (Image credit: PEDRO MATTEY)

Title: While sanctions still cripple a shattered Syria, one Jewish leader returns from exile
Description: During the Assad regimes, Western nations placed crippling economic sanctions on the country. Some have been lifted, but most are still in place, so how does a country shattered by civil war rebuild? And we follow the return to Damascus of one US Syrian Jewish leader, after decades in exile.

Title: The view from Greenland: 'We don't want to be Americans'
Description: President Trump's calls for the U.S. to take over Greenland have sparked alarm and outrage.Denmark, which is responsible for Greenland's security, recently announced that it would further boost its defense spending.And a recent poll found 85 percent of Greenlanders are opposed to being part of the United States.Parliamentary candidate Naaja Nathanielsen is one of them.It isn't clear whether Trump's ambitions for Greenland will take. Title: Tell us your story about car insurance premiums
Description: Car insurance premiums have been soaring. NPR wants to hear about what you've experienced in your premium costs, and why. (Image credit: Brandon Bell)

Title: A snowshoe trek in the Adirondack Mountains on a classic winter day
Description: Snowshoeing in the Adirondacks on a winter day with chickadees for company (Image credit: Brian Mann)

Title: Rollback of diversity efforts leaves teachers wondering about effects on Black History Month
Description: The Education Department's efforts to keep racial diversity out of schools has left educators wondering how and when to teach students about Black history, especially during Black History Month. (Image credit: Kassidy Arena)

Title: Fabric giant Joann is going out of business and closing all of its 800 stores
Description: The crafts retailer formerly known as Jo-Ann Fabrics had been struggling financially for several years following a DIY-driven uptick in sales during the early days of the pandemic. (Image credit: Joe Raedle)

Title: The odds of a 'city-killer' asteroid hitting Earth have fallen to zero
Description: After weeks at the top of the Sentry list at the Center for Near-Earth Object Studies, the asteroid 2024 YR4 is no longer considered a threat to Earth. (Image credit: AP)

Title: How is Pope Francis doing? The Vatican says he rested well and met church officials
Description: Pope Francis 'rested well throughout the night' in the hospital, the Vatican says, and even met with Vatican officials to sign several documents linked to sainthood designations on Monday. (Image credit: Luciano Gonzalez)

Title: Supreme Court throws out death sentence, murder conviction of Okla. death row inmate
Description: The court reversed the state court's judgement and sent the case back for a new trial. (Image credit: Larry French)

Title: From deportations to health care, state lawmakers are key for much of Trump's domestic agenda
Description: Federal power only goes so far. State governors and legislatures have wide authority over local law enforcement, schools, health and how cities and counties handle immigration. (Image credit: Pool)

Title: Joy Reid fired from MSNBC amid network shakeup
Description: Reid is a longtime political commentator who has been vocal on progressive issues and sharply critical of President Trump. (Image credit: Arturo Holmes)

Title: Who is Alice Marie Johnson, Trump's newly appointed 'pardon czar'?
Description: Johnson, now 69, was facing life in prison without the possibility of parole for being a first-time nonviolent drug offender. (Image credit: Chip Somodevilla)

Title: Trump's funding freeze threatens key river. And, U.S. votes against Ukraine peace plan
Description: Trump's funding freezes could threaten the Colorado River. Some money was intended to keep the shrinking river flowing. And, the U.S. voted against a U.N. peace resolution for Ukraine. (Image credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Title: 5 signs that a U.S.-Europe split is widening
Description: As the Trump administration ramps up its rhetoric against Ukraine and NATO, European countries are taking note — with increasing alarm. (Image credit: Tobias Schwarz)

Title: Top Ukrainian official says Kyiv will refuse any 'bad' peace deal
Description: Ihor Brusylo, deputy head of Ukraine's President's Office, tells NPR Trump is a 'peacemaker and dealmaker,' while expressing hope the U.S. continues to provide aid to Ukraine. (Image credit: Richard Drew)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: U.S. opposes a resolution demanding that Russia withdraw from Ukraine, Trump funding freeze includes payments to keep the Colorado River flowing, massive child sex abuse trial begins in France.

Title: Syrian Jews return to Damascus hoping to rebuild a community
Description: The overthrow of the Assad regime in Syria paved the way for a historic visit, with Syrian Jews returning from the U.S. to Damascus for the first time in three decades, hoping to rebuild community.

Title: President of the Iowa Farmers Union discusses anticipated Agriculture Department cuts
Description: NPR's A Martinez speaks with Aaron Lehman, a fifth-generation farmer who is president of the Iowa Farmers Union, about anticipated cuts to Department of Agriculture programs.

Title: Former U.S. ambassador to Hungary discusses democratic decay under PM Orbán
Description: NPR's Leila Fadel speaks with David Pressman, former U.S. ambassador to Hungary, about that country's democratic decay under Prime Minister Viktor Orbán.

Title: U.S. votes against U.N. resolution urging Russia's withdrawal from Ukraine
Description: The U.N. General Assembly adopted a resolution Monday condemning Russian aggression and calling for the immediate withdrawal of Russian forces from Ukraine. The U.S. joined Russia in opposing it.

Title: Foreign policy expert Stephen Walt discusses America's shifting alliances
Description: As the Trump administration aligns itself more closely with Russia, foreign policy expert Stephen Walt at Harvard University discusses the repercussions of America's shifting alliances.

Title: French surgeon on trial accused of raping or abusing 299 people, mostly children
Description: A former surgeon in France, now 74, is on trial for the alleged rape or sexual abuse of 299 victims, most of them children. Investigators say the violence spanned more than three decades.

Title: Pakistan's cricket fans rejoice as country hosts first major tournament in years
Description: Pakistanis have found reason to celebrate as the country hosts a major international cricket tournament for the first time in years.

Title: Top Ukrainian official says Kyiv will refuse any 'bad' peace deal
Description: Ihor Brusylo {EE-hor BROO-see-low}, deputy head of the Office of the President of Ukraine, speaks with NPR's Steve Inskeep about the latest talks of a deal with Russia, and the U.S.'s shifting position on backing Kyiv.

Title: Retired FBI agent gives initial impressions of Kash Patel and Dan Bongino
Description: The new top two leaders at the FBI are Trump loyalists with no prior experience at the bureau. NPR asks retired FBI special agent Thomas J. Baker for his impressions of Kash Patel and Dan Bongino.

Title: What to expect at the FBI under the leadership of Kash Patel and Dan Bongino
Description: The new top two leaders at the FBI are Trump loyalists with no prior experience at the bureau. NPR's Leila Fadel asks retired FBI special agent Thomas J. Baker for his impressions of both men.

Title: Trump funding freeze includes payments to keep the Colorado River flowing
Description: President Biden promised billions in funds to farmers and others to not take water from the Colorado River. President Trump is halting some of those funds, leaving questions about the river's future. (Image credit: Mario Tama/Getty Images)

Title: Clint Hill, the Secret Service agent who tried to shield the Kennedys, dies at 93
Description: Hill received Secret Service awards and was promoted for his actions that day, but for decades blamed himself for Kennedy's death, saying he would gladly have given his life to save the president. (Image credit: James W. Ike Altgens)

Title: Germany's historic election. And the impact of 3 years of war in Ukraine
Description: The man poised to become Germany's new Chancellor says the US administration doesn't care about the fate of Europe. And, on the third anniversary of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine what has been the impact of the largest conflict in Europe since the second world war? (Image credit: Marcus Brandt)

Title: The Panama Canal needs more water. The solution is a dam that could displace thousands
Description: More than 2,000 people could be displaced by the construction of the Río Indio dam. The Panama Canal Authority says the dam solves a long-term water shortage problem. (Image credit: Tomas Ayuso for NPR)

Title: Layoffs at federal housing agency HUD would worsen homelessness, employees say
Description: The Trump administration wants massive staff cuts at the federal housing agency. Employees and others say they could end up making record-high homelessness even worse.

Title: The changes that lie ahead for Germany after Sunday's election
Description: German voters gave the far-right AfD party second place in elections, which will make the Christian Democrat Party's Friedrich Merz the next chancellor.

Title: Prosecutor Fani Willis is fighting to keep her case against President Trump alive
Description: Donald Trump and Atlanta prosecutor Fani Willis began their second terms in office a few weeks apart. Here's a look at how their fates have diverged over the last year.

Title: World leaders are in Ukraine's capital to mark 3 years since Russia launched its war
Description: As the U.S. turns away from Ukraine, more than a dozen leaders gather in Kyiv as Ukrainians mark three years since Russia's invasion and ongoing war.

Title: Western sanctions are holding Syria back from rebuilding, locals say
Description: Western countries have imposed layers of crippling sanctions on Syria for decades. Syrians say the sanctions are impeding any hope of rebuilding a country shattered by civil war.

Title: Miami Beach is again cracking down to keep spring breakers away
Description: Miami Beach is again cracking down on spring breakers this year after major restrictions kept large crowds away in 2024.

Title: Trump and Macron meet in Washington as Europe pleads for continued help for Ukraine
Description: In a conversation between President Trump and French President Emmanuel Macron in the Oval Office Monday, the two leaders seemed friendly even when they appeared far apart on the war in Ukraine. (Image credit: Ludovic Marin)

Title: U.S. votes against a U.N. resolution urging Russia's withdrawal from Ukraine
Description: The European-backed resolution that was approved demands Russia immediately withdraw its forces. The Trump administration had offered a competing resolution that did not mention Russian aggression. (Image credit: Julia Demaree Nikhinson/AP)

Title: DHS memo lays out plans to detain migrants at Fort Bliss and other U.S. bases
Description: The Trump administration is developing plans to build immigration detention facilities on bases nationwide, a step that could significantly expand the military's role in immigration enforcement. (Image credit: U.S. Army Sgt. 1st Class Nicholas J. De La Pena)

Title: Mikaela Shiffrin seals legacy as one of skiing's greatest with historic 100 World Cup wins
Description: After a bruising crash last November, Mikaela Shiffrin dominated the slopes on Sunday and made skiing history once again. (Image credit: Stefano Guidi)

Title: Who is Dan Bongino? What to know about Trump's pick for FBI deputy director
Description: Dan Bongino has been chosen as the FBI's second-in-command, a job that doesn't need Senate confirmation. Here's what to know about the Secret Service agent-turned-conservative media personality. (Image credit: Calla Kessler)

Title: Pope rests in his 10th day of hospitalization but remains in critical condition
Description: Francis, 88, had remained in critical condition throughout the weekend after severe breathing difficulties were reported. (Image credit: ALBERTO PIZZOLI)

Title: Macron, Trump to discuss Ukraine peace plan. And, Greenpeace faces $300 million lawsuit
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron is set to present the European peace plan for Ukraine to President Trump today. And, Greenpeace faces a lawsuit that could shut it down. (Image credit: Win McNamee)

Title: A 10-year-old's story of family immigration that spans three continents
Description: A California fourth-grader's interview with her grandfather, who was forced out of Uganda before moving to the U.S., is one of our outstanding podcasts. (Image credit: Janet Woojeong Lee)

Title: Republicans' love/hate relationship with the Education Department
Description: President Trump has made clear he wants to close the U.S. Department of Education, but Republicans seem torn on just how far to go. (Image credit: Jon Cherry)

Title: 3 years on, here's what to keep an eye on in the Ukraine war — and efforts to end it
Description: Thousands of civilians have been killed since Russia launched its full-scale invasion on Feb. 24, 2022. Amid a stark shift in U.S. policy, Ukrainians want the war to end — but not on Russia's terms. (Image credit: Anton Shtuka for NPR)

Title: Federal workers feel betrayed and alone in Trump administration's chaotic purge
Description: Mike Macans is one of an unknown number of Small Business Administration employees who were fired, unfired and fired again as part of the Trump administration's deep cuts to the federal workforce. (Image credit: Ash Adams for NPR)

Title: Morning news brief
Description: French President Emmanuel Macron to meet President Trump in D.C., center-right opposition party wins in Germany's election, Greenpeace faces $300 million lawsuit after Dakota Access Pipeline protests.

Title: Israel delays Palestinian prisoner release, while sending tanks to occupied West Bank
Description: Israel delayed a Palestinian prisoner release, accusing Hamas of 'humiliating' hostages, while also sending tanks into the occupied West Bank for the first time in decades.

Title: Trial starts for man charged with killing 7 during July Fourth parade near Chicago
Description: Trial gets underway for a man charged with killing 7 people during a 2022 July 4th parade near Chicago. His father served time for helping his then-teenage son secure a gun license, despite red flags.

Title: NPR listeners tell us about the local Black heroes making a difference in their lives
Description: Black History Month often invokes the past, but Black history is made every day. We asked NPR listeners to tell us about local Black figures making a difference in their communities.

Title: French President Emmanuel Macron to meet President Trump in Washington
Description: French President Macron will meet Trump Monday and is expected to present the European plan for peace in Ukraine. Trump abruptly reversed alliances last week, blaming Ukraine for causing the war.

Title: What are the prospects for peace in Ukraine 3 years after Russia launched its war?
Description: Three years after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, what has been the impact of the largest conflict in Europe since World War II? How does the U.S. pivot toward Russia affect peace prospects?

Title: Email asking federal workers to detail accomplishments stokes confusion and anger
Description: Federal employees were told they have until the end of Monday to detail what they accomplished last week or face firing. Some bosses said to hold on before replying to the email, stoking confusion.

Title: Historian Anne Applebaum breaks down what Trump's alignment with Russia means
Description: Historian Anne Applebaum says America's shifting alliances with anti-democratic nations, particularly Russia, raise questions about the state of world order and long-standing alliances. (Image credit: Susan Walsh)

Title: Anne Applebaum discusses America's shifting alliances toward anti-democratic nations
Description: Anne Applebaum, a writer with 'The Atlantic,' talks with NPR's Leila Fadel to unpack the implications of America's shifting alliances with anti-democratic nations, particularly Russia.

Title: Trump names conservative media personality Dan Bongino as FBI deputy director
Description: The selection places two staunch Trump allies atop the nation's premier federal law enforcement agency at a time when Democrats are concerned that the president could seek to target his adversaries. (Image credit: Susan Walsh/AP)

Title: A French surgeon is on trial accused of raping or abusing 299 people, mostly children
Description: The trial comes as French activists are pushing to lift taboos that surround sexual abuse. The most prominent case was that of Gisèle Pélicot, who was raped by her now ex-husband and dozens of others. (Image credit: Aurelien Morissard)
